newsitem.title: POLAND: OPINION - POLISH NOBE MACROECONOMIC FORECAST.
newsitem.headline: OPINION - POLISH NOBE MACROECONOMIC FORECAST.

text.p: NOBE Independent Centre for Economic Studies
Quarterly forecasts of the economic development of Poland
The Polish economy was growing by more than 7 percent
during the last two quarters. However, the fast growth was
accompanied by a rapid deterioration of the current account
balance and the growing trade deficit. The level of the current
account deficit is still acceptable but the negative trend
should be stopped over the next 6-12 months to avoid more
serious economic perturbations. The growth of domestic credit
and consumption should be slowed down to stabilise the curent
account deficit at the level below four percent of GDP. In our
view no drastic policy measures are necessary to achieve this
target. However, some policy moves are unavoidable and likely
to take place despite the coming general elections.
Four main factors influenced the economic performance of
Poland in the first quarter of 1997.
Firstly, the dynamics of domestic consumption remained very
high both due to a fast growth of wages and consumer credit as
well as because of the continuing investment boom. Total growth
of domestic consumption exceeded 11 percent compared to the
same period year ago.
Secondly, the rapid growth was accompanied by even faster
increase in imports (above 20 percent), in a large part due to
purchases of capital goods.
Thirdly, the growth rates of exports started to pick up
slowly. Nevertheless, as the dynamics of imports remained still
significantly higher than the dynamics of exports, the external
balance deteriorated considerably. The balance of payments
trade deficit increased during the last six months by almost $6
billion and the current account deficit by $2.5 billion.
Fourthly, inflationary pressure kept falling despite the
fast demand growth and a relatively expansionary monetary
policy.
The observed growth pattern is not sustainable over the
longer period. The deterioration of the external balance has
not reached dangerous levels yet, could cause problems 4-5
quarters from now if it countinues to worsen. However, we are
relatively optimistic, as there are reasons to believe that the
situation may improve without drastic policy measures.
1. The trade deficit is growing rapidly, but its level is
still acceptable. A trade deficit is a normal phenomenon in a
fast growing economy importing foreign capital. The current
account deficit was about one percent of GDP in 1996 and is
likely to grow to 3.5-3.8 percent in 1997. This is still a
level that can be comfortably financed by capital inflows.
However, any further deterioration in 1998 may be
dangerous. That means, that although Poland has got some room
for manoeuvre to accomodate the unavoidable deterioration of
the external account in 1997, the trend of the rapid
deterioration should be stopped over the next four quarters.
2. We expect some improvement in exports to take place
mainly due to the faster growth in Western Europe and despite
the weak German Mark. Such an improvement will not be enough to
restore the external equilibrium of Poland, but may help to
curb the growth of the deficit.
3. Under these circumstances current growth rates of
investment and consumer demand (over 20 percent and almost 8
percent respectively) are not sustainable over the longer
period. Our assessment is that the growth of investment should
gradually cool down to 12-15 percent over the next four
quarters and the growth of consumption to about five percent.
4. No drastic policy measures are necessary or desirable to
achieve this target. Monetary policy is the key here. As growth
of domestic credit should be curbed, there is no room for
interest rate cuts. To the contrary, NBP may slightly increase
the basic rates in the coming months, or continue using other
instruments that increase the price of money. Probably no
one-off devaluation will be necessary, and the crawling peg
will continue at its present rate of one percent a month.
The crawl is unlikely to be be cut below 0.9-1 percent a
month over the next four quarters. Finally, as the budget
deficit is still under control, we do not see reasons for
fiscal adjustment. With a slowdown in GDP growth, and low
inflation, the budget may find itself under some pressure in
the second half of 1997. The deficit, even if the target is
exceeded, should not reach three percent of GDP.
As the outcome of current trends and policy changes we
expect the growth rate of domestic consumption to slow down to
seven percent in the last quarter of 1997 on lower investment
growth and lower private consumption.
The growth rate of exports is not likely to exceed that of
imports before 1998. GDP growth will fall to about five percent
in the last quarter of 1997. The annual growth rate in 1997
will be about six percent, very similar to GDP growth in 1996.
GDP growth may start picking up only after the trend of current
account deterioration is stopped.

Table 2 shows projected inflationary developments in the
next four quarters. Weakening indexation mechainsms, more rigid
monetary policy, and possible slow growth of food prices will
result in the continuous slowdown of consumer prices. The
process of the general fall of inflationary expectations may be
significantly disrupted if devaluation expectations due to the
lack of a transparent exchange rate policy.
Producer price growth will stabilize around 11 percent. The
fall of PPI will resume in 1998 (to a one-digit level) after
the crawling peg devaluation of the zloty is slowed down below
0.9 percent in a month.
